thread.title: After three years, E-R Sessions produces its 200th episode
thread.title_full: After three years, E-R Sessions produces its 200th episode

posts.author: Bianca Quilantan bquilantan@chicoer.com @biancaquilan on Twitter
posts.title: After three years, E-R Sessions produces its 200th episode
posts.text:
5. “Last Train to Georgia” by The Union Drifters 
Find these and all the other performances at www.chicoer.com/sessions . 
Chico >> For three years, local musicians have shined in the Chico E-R Sessions spotlight. Now, the video series is celebrating its 200th episode, a milestone deserving of its own time to shine. 
Chico E-R Sessions was started in January 2014 by then-Enterprise-Record Entertainment Editor Leila Rodriguez and Ernesto Rivera to showcase local artists and musicians passing through town. 
Rodriguez said Sessions was inspired but the Trolley series in San Diego, which features famous artists who play music in red trolley cars. She said Rivera and herself were drawn to the aspect of on-the-spot, one-take performances. Together, they brought the idea to Enterprise-Record Editor David Little. Be a featured artist 
Are you interested in participating in E-R Sessions or would like to suggest new artists? Email the arts and entertainment editor at . 
“The scene is just so saturated with amazing people and we wanted to showcase that and all of the incredible acts that come through Chico as well,” Rodriguez said. 
Little gave them the green light. They were then tasked with finding at least five artists to film, which ranged from local artists to visiting bands. To this day, Rodriguez said the first five videos they produced are her favorite. Chico’s music community was also receptive to the idea when it came out. 
“We’ve had really good feedback on it,” she said. “Jason Tate, a bass player who filmed with us, said he would play the videos just in the background at work and said it was the perfect Chico playlist—a slice of the music scene.” 
Sessions started as Rodriguez and Rivera’s passion project. And, although the inspiration came from the Trolley series, most of the time, the videos are shot in Bidwell Park. The location they shoot at usually depends on the genre and feel of the artists’ music. They’ve shot videos all over town in obscure places like Cedar Grove, a barn, the Chico Paper Company, Rodriguez’s backyard and even on a bus. 
“We went on the bus before, and that was really special,” she said. “They gave us a private bus to film in and I wanted to do something a little different than just sit and sing. But, we film everywhere and anywhere.” 
Sometimes the musicians’ sounds would get tricky to balance because of competing natural sounds from their scene of choice. Often times, the team has to find a way to avoid helicopters buzzing, planes flying, dogs barking and even passersby — specifically a man with a flute who wanted to play in the background of the shoot. The first videos also were only acoustic because they had one microphone, no equipment and the team didn’t know how to edit sound. 
Rodriguez said when James Chato joined the team a year ago, the professionalism of the videos soared because of his sound engineering skills. She also jokes that the professionalism started on Chato’s first day when he showed up in slacks, compared to the more casually dressed team members. Chato swears he doesn’t remember wearing slacks, but from there, “the rest is all a blur.” Advertisement 
The third team member is Jeffrey Fox, who Rodriguez said “is very on the scene all the time and snags artists for videos.” 
Although the team has evolved over the years with Rivera’s departure and new additions, Rodriguez, Chato and Fox’s team dynamic is what makes the video series successful. Each team member has a skill set that complements the others’. 
“Jeff has a totally different aesthetic and is just so good with artists and talking with them. I tend to be quiet and technical, and James is good with talking to them too,” Rodriguez said. “The three of us together, it works well.” 
The 200th episode features Max Minardi, who has been an artist on the Session’s bucket list since the series started. Scheduling conflicts were the biggest issue because of Minardi’s busy music schedule. A few years back, the team and Minardi were able to connect. But, when they finally were able to settle on a date for the video, the microphone went missing at the shoot. 
Minardi said he was a big fan of Sessions because for the small community, the videos are “making something that lasts and incorporating the local talent and making a big thing of it. 
“I like sessions like this because it gives people a chance to really sit down with the song,” he said. “One of my favorite parts of Sessions is you can visit it as many times as you want and you can really dig really deep in to aspects of the song that you might not hear in a live show.” 
Missing microphone and busy schedules aside, the video that has been two years in the making was finally filmed in the woodsy Cedar Grove in Bidwell Park. 
By the next hundred episode milestone, Rodriguez and Chato said they still have a bucket list of artists they hope to feature. On the top of their list are local artists like Solar Estates and the Yule Logs. Chato also said he’s looking to get nationally-recognized bands that tour through Chico. 
“It’s been a great learning experience,” Rodriguez said. “But it’s also been a privilege to have these artists entrust us to showcase their music weekly.” 
Reach reporter Bianca Quilantan at 896-7758.

posts.title: South Korean government protests inclusion on EU tax haven blacklist
posts.text: South Korean government protests inclusion on EU tax haven blacklist  18  18 KST A summit of the European Union (Yonhap News) The Special Tax Treatment Control Act was criticized for providing preferential tax treatment to foreign investors After the European Union (EU) included South Korea on a blacklist of tax havens on Dec. 5,the government shot back that this was as an “infringement of taxation sovereignty” and a “violation of international standards.” But some think that Seoul was complacent in its response to the EU’s plans. “The EU’s decision does not conform to the standards of international bodies such as the OECD and is also in violation of international agreements,” said South Korea’s Ministry of Strategy and Finance in a press release on Dec. 6 responding to the country’s inclusion on the EU’s list of 17 “uncooperative regions,” which is to say tax havens. “We proposed working with the EU to analyze the harmfulness of the programs in question and to consider improvements to those programs by mutual consent, but the EU included us on the list because we did not promise to revise or eliminate these programs by the end of 2018. For the EU to insist that a non-member state abide by EU standards constitutes a violation of taxation sovereignty,” the Ministry went on to say in the press release. The day before, the EU’s Finance and Economy Committee, which was attended by the finance ministers of the 28 countries in the bloc, placed South Korea, along with Panama, Tunisia, Barbados and other countries, on a blacklist of “uncooperative regions” regarded as tax havens. South Korea was included on the list because of its Special Tax Treatment Control Act, which gives five to seven years of concessions on corporate and income tax for companies that set up shop in a free economic zone. The EU regards the act as a “harmful preferential tax regime,” or in other words legislation that explicitly gives tax benefits to transactions with foreigners. Seoul contends that the EU’s measures run contrary to international standards. The OECD and the G20 have been running a program to counter base erosion and profit shifting (BEPS) strategies as part of efforts to prevent tax evasion, and in September they concluded that South Korea’s subsidies for foreign investors did not constitute a harmful preferential tax regime. Those organizations had limited the scope of tax avoidance activities to sectors with high mobility, such as finance and services. The South Korean government is under fire, however, for having done little to address the EU’s announcement early this year that South Korea would be included on the tax haven blacklist. During negotiations with the EU, countries including Switzerland, Turkey and Hong Kong avoided inclusion on the list by promising to revise their tax systems. In the end, all the regions on the blacklist except for South Korea are either small economies or self-governing islands. “While this does seem unfair, the truth is that South Korea is nearly the only country in the OECD that explicitly provides preferential tax treatment to foreign investors. We will take this opportunity to discuss tax concessions for foreigners in light of the interests of domestic industry and international standards,” said an official from the Ministry. By Bang Jun-ho, staff reporter Please direct questions or comments to [english@hani.co.kr]

thread.title_full: Hunterston Turbine D-Day this month

posts.title: Hunterston Turbine D-Day this month
posts.text:
Hunterston Turbine D-Day this month Hunterston Turbine D-Day this month 
It is D-Day for the Hunterston turbines with a decision expected to be taken by Scottish Ministers this month. As we go to press, campaigners from Fairlie are gathering at Holyrood in bid to persuade MSPs to rethink the planning bill. Late submissions to the Scottish Government Planning and Environmental Appeals Division has resulted in decision date being pushed back to Friday December 8. Operators SSE have turned off the turbines since October, awaiting the final outcome. Representatives from Fairlie Community Council are joining other communities to gather outside the Scottish Parliament, urging MSPs to rethink new planning legislation that is being introduced. Fairlie Community Council chairman Rita Holmes and secretary Karla Tully are joining the demonstration which has been called in response to the Scottish Planning Bill – expected to be laid imminently before parliament. The villagers have been working with the grassroots Planning Democracy campaign who have been at the forefront of calling for an equal right of appeal to be included in the legislation, to allow communities the option to challenge controversial planning decisions. A statement from Fairlie Community Council read; “There is something very wrong, when a rejection by the Reporter can be appealed by SSE the wind energy company, but a consent cannot be appealed by the community. This despite the fact NAC have already asked that SSE`s Appeal be dismissed. “ Clare Symonds (Chair of Planning Democracy) said: “What we are looking for is a level playing field when it comes to big planning decisions that can create major disruption to people’s lives or seriously impact upon the environment.” “The lack of an equal right to appeal is seen by communities as one of the most unpopular and unjust aspects of the current planning system. Research commissioned earlier this year by the Scottish Government found e that communities have a “serious lack of trust, respect and confidence in the planning system”. As things stand, the only option available to communities who wish to challenge a decision by a local or national government body is a costly judicial review.” An SSE spokesperson said: “The Hunterston site has brought multiple benefits to the offshore wind industry as well as the local community over the past five years, SSE hopes to continue these benefits through the two year time extension and awaits the decision of the Scottish Government.”

thread.title: Acute oxygen-sensing by the carotid body: a rattlebag of molecular mechanisms
thread.title_full: Acute oxygen-sensing by the carotid body: a rattlebag of molecular mechanisms

posts.author: Alexandros Sfakianakis (noreply@blogger.com)
posts.title: Acute oxygen-sensing by the carotid body: a rattlebag of molecular mechanisms
posts.text:
Abstract The molecular underpinnings of the oxygen-sensitivity of the carotid body Type I cells are becoming better defined as research begins to identify potential interactions between previously separate theories. Nevertheless, the field of oxygen-chemoreception still presents the general observer with a bewildering array of potential signalling pathways by which a fall in oxygen levels might initiate Type I cell activation. The purpose of this brief review is to address five of the current oxygen-sensing hypotheses.
The lactate/Olfr78 hypothesis of oxygen chemotransduction. The role mitochondrial ATP and metabolism may have in chemotransduction. The AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) hypothesis and its current role in oxygen-sensing by the carotid body. Reactive oxygen species as key transducers in the oxygen-sensing cascade. The mechanisms by which H 2 S, reactive oxygen species and Heme Oxygenase may integrate to provide a rapid oxygen-sensing transduction system. Over the previous fifteen years several lines of research into acute hypoxic chemotransduction mechanisms have focused on the integration of mitochondrial and membrane signalling. This review places an emphasis on the subplasmalemmal-mitochondrial microenvironment in Type I cells and how theories of acute oxygen-sensing are increasingly dependent on functional interaction within this microenvironment (see Abstract Figure).

thread.section_title: Do You Want To Be A Wine Connoisseur? These Tips Can Help! – singledomain48jean's blog
thread.title: Do You Want To Be A Wine Connoisseur? These Tips Can Help!
thread.title_full: Do You Want To Be A Wine Connoisseur? These Tips Can Help!

posts.author: singledomain48jean
posts.title: Do You Want To Be A Wine Connoisseur? These Tips Can Help!
posts.text:
With regards to wine, we could all stand to know a bit more than we actually do. Being an expert in wine is a tell tale way to show off your sophistication, but this is much easier said that done. Luckily, the following article has a wealth of information that will help you learn all there is to learn about wine.
Attend as many wine tastings that you can during the course of the year. This can be very beneficial for you as it allows you to get an idea of some of the newer wines that are on the market. This will help you to gain a better appreciation for all wine has to offer.
Pinot Grigio is a natural partner to a seafood meal. The flavors complement each other well. Other white wines go equally well with seafood. It makes for a tasty combination when you pair white wine with seafood.
You can make amazing pairings with your favorite wine. For example, you can pair a Chardonnay with either Gouda or Provolone. For http://www.news18.com/news/lifestyle/food-these-are-the-best-italian-restaurants-outside-of-italy-1559837.html , such as Cheddar, opt for a Cabernet such as Cabernet Sauvignon or Cabernet Franc. Zinfandel wines go beautifully with the more delicate cheeses such as Feta and Gouda.
Not every white wine must be chilled before serving. They are not the same and have different serving requirements. While sauvignon blanc is best served chilled, wines like chardonnay and pinot gris taste better at warmer temperatures.
If you buy boxed wine, you can filter this into a nice glass decanter to improve the way that it looks. This is a great trick that you can use if you have to serve friends at a party or dinner. This will allow you to save money while giving off an elegant image.
White wines do not always need to be chilled before serving. They are not the same and have different serving requirements. As an example, Pinot Gris is best served closer to room temperature.
If you are in the market for champagne for a wedding or other festive event, consider a sparkling wine instead. Sparkling wines are typically from California, and they taste similar to a Champagne. They are almost always less expensive, making it easier to afford a large quantity for big events.
A decanter can be a useful product to have. If you have not been able to get one, or if you do not like them because of the time involved in using them, think about getting an aerator instead. They fulfill similar functions, and they are often easier to use.
So many tastes are available in wine, so have fun with them. When analyzing wines, you’ll be breaking them down by their construction, pairings, and flavors. Instead, just enjoy yourself and choose things that you like.
Keep a journal just for wine. The easiest way to keep track of the wines that you enjoy and the ones that you do not like is to keep a list of them. You can also include the foods that you drank them with so that you can repeat the experience if you like.
You can read as much as you like about wine, but ultimately, you have to decide for yourself if you like it or not. Price often doesn’t matter. You may like an inexpensive bottle of red wine much more than a costlier version. Don’t apologize for your tastes. Drink what you enjoy.
Making sure a Spanish wine is kept fresh is easily done, but there are different methods depending on its type. Rioja lasts up to seven years after bottling, and it is popular here. Storing your wine in a place that is dark and cool, such as a basement or closet, can really help to ensure you get the maximum flavor from your wine.
If you are out on a date or with someone you want to impress, do not order a wine that you have not had before. Try to order wine that you are familiar with, or know that you like. Be http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/howard/howard-magazine/bs-mg-ho-howard-county-best-restaurants-2017-story.html in your own time, when you are not out in public.
No matter, how much you enjoy a particular type of wine, do not purchase a whole case of it. As your palate becomes more educated, your taste will change enough that you prefer another variety of wine. This could leave you with a supply of wine in storage that you no longer care for.

Now that you have more information about wine, you can show off. Talk to other people about your new knowledge, and buy wines based on what you now know. You will discover that wine tastes better when you know something about it, and you can have a much better time with it.

posts.title: Eminem Details New Album "Revival" Featuring Ed Sheeran and Alicia Keys
posts.text:
more eminem videos » 
Eminem has revealed the tracklist and guestlist for his forthcoming album, Revival . Beyoncé, Ed Sheeran, Pink and Alicia Keys lead the list of featured artists that will join the rapper on the new record. Revival is due out on Friday, December 15th. 
The 19-song album will open with the previously-released "Walk on Water" which features Beyoncé. Sheeran appears on a song called "River", and Pink on "Need Me". Eminem recently appeared on the track "Revenge" on Pink's album Beautiful Trauma , which hit number one earlier this year. Other wide-ranging Revival musical guests include X Ambassadors, Skylar Grey, Kehlani and Phresher. 
Revival is the first Eminem album since 2013's The Marshall Mathers LP 2 . The rapper began teasing the forthcoming LP in October with an ads that initially appeared to be the marketing campaign for a new pharmaceutical drug. 
Eminem has not announced a tour at this time, but with the album's release just around the corner, hopes are high that a full set of concert dates will be unveiled in the near future. 
Revival tracklist: 1. "Walk on Water" (featuring Beyoncé) 2. "Believe"

thread.title_full: Hall of Fame QB Warren Moon sued for sexual harassment

posts.author: The Associated Press
posts.title: Hall of Fame QB Warren Moon sued for sexual harassment
posts.text:
Hall of Fame QB Warren Moon sued for sexual harassment By The Associated Press # Comments 
Hall of Fame quarterback Warren Moon has been accused of sexual harassment by an assistant for his sports marketing firm, according to a lawsuit filed in California. 
The civil lawsuit was filed Monday in Orange County Superior Court. According to court documents, Wendy Haskell alleges Moon made "unwanted and unsolicited" sexual advances as part of her role as his assistant working for Sports 1 Marketing. Moon is the co-founder and president of the company. 
The Washington Post first reported on the lawsuit Wednesday. The 61-year-old Moon has been working as a radio commentator for the Seattle Seahawks. The team announced later Wednesday that "We have accepted Warren Moon's request for a leave of absence as the club's radio analyst." 
Moon played parts of 17 seasons in the NFL with Houston, Minnesota, Seattle and Kansas City. He threw for 49,325 yards and 291 touchdowns in the regular season and was elected to the Hall of Fame in 2006. The former University of Washington star led Edmonton to five Canadian Football League titles before playing in the NFL. Advertisement 
According to the lawsuit, Haskell was hired as an executive assistant to Moon in the summer of 2017. The lawsuit alleges that Haskell was forced to sleep in the same bed with Moon on business trips while wearing lingerie. Haskell says in the lawsuit that she complained about the arrangement but that Moon responded "this was the way it was." Additionally, the lawsuit claims Haskell was required to keep the bathroom door unlocked while she showered and Moon repeatedly entered the room. 
Haskell also claimed she was drugged by Moon during a trip to Mexico in October. The lawsuit alleges that Moon acknowledged drugging Haskell because he thought she wasn't "having fun." She also claims Moon pulled off her swimsuit during the Mexico trip. 
The lawsuit claims that Haskell reported Moon's behavior to Sports 1 Marketing CEO David Meltzer but the company did not investigate her claims. Haskell claims she was demoted after making the complaints. 
Haskell's attorney, Diane L. Fitzgerald, told The Washington Post her client had decided to go public with the suit. 
"She was expecting to further her career in the sports marketing industry," Fitzgerald told The Post. "She had no idea that her job duties were going to involve that kind of perverse protocol."

thread.title: The myth of “having an impact”
thread.title_full: The myth of “having an impact”

posts.author: Mostafa Ismail
posts.title: The myth of “having an impact”
posts.text:
I want to change the world. Is this desire driven by an insecure ego in need of attention, one searching for glory and eternity, or is it a sincere honest desire to just make the world a better place…
I don’t know…
But the moment I decided that I was somehow capable of changing the world, everything changed. I was suddenly more energetic, more disciplined and just more joyful about my life.
But..
My day to day activities didn’t change, I was still a student. I was now attending my classes, and focusing on my studies, because of the ambitions I had set out for myself, but nothing really changed.
I felt trapped.
I felt torn between a voice telling me to just stop everything and just “grind out” my own path, and a voice that was telling me to be patient, and that the big change was coming, the big impact was going to happen soon.
I thought that the bigger and more ambitious my purpose was, the stronger I will be, and the more disciplined I would be, and so I constantly told myself that I have to aim higher, and ask for more.
I couldn’t have been further from the truth.
The bigger and more ambitious goals didn’t serve me, but they served my ego, providing satisfaction by painting an image of upcoming glory and recognition, and so I’ve learnt that…
Ego is the enemy 
This is a great book by Ryan Holiday , and I haven’t even read it, but it’s inspired me in countless ways, it’s shown me where my error was.
I learnt about it from a Youtube book summary by Fight Mediocrity. In it, Holiday explains how he reached success very early in his twenties, thanks to good fortune and luck more than anything else, and how his ego used that success to construct a “narrative”, where all the success was due to his skills and hard work, and where all the failures never occurred.
This was it! This is why I felt trapped, I was trapped by my own ego.
I thought that the key to success was setting huge goals that sound completely crazy, but I didn’t realise that these goals had to be centred on me bettering myself, and not on changing the world, or even affecting other people.
Changing the world and being recognized are desires that stem from our ego which seeks superiority, while bettering oneself has its basis in humility, since I need to admit I’m not good enough to start doing the work to improve myself.
My goals are now based on getting better at whatever I do, I don’t care about having an impact. 
To illustrate this, I will share with you the small but valuable experience that taught me this.
I arrived at university a year and a half ago. Back in school I was “the smart kid who did nothing and still got the best grades”. This made me feel good about myself, or more accurately, made my ego very satisfied.
But when I got to university, this was crushed completely, if I didn’t put the work, I didn’t get the grades. This was frustrating and destabilizing.
My self-esteem and my confidence were battered, because these were built almost entirely on external factors, such as my grades, my friends’ opinion of me, etc..
I had to admit to myself that I wasn’t that smart after all, that the only reason I was that good at school was actually because I paid really close attention in class, although I tried very hard not to show it. And that the only way I was succeeding at this (University), was by working really hard, and asking for help from those around me.
The result is: I’m a better student. 
I also had to learn to build my confidence and my self-image on internal rather than external factors. I build my confidence on my hard work, and on what I create, not what grades I get, or how talented I think I am at something.
I learnt to put my head down, and to work hard to achieve something small but important and it makes day to day life so much more enjoyable!
I’m no longer pressuring myself with this abstract idea of having an impact, of changing the world, but I’m simply bettering myself, and if the time is right, and it’s what the world needs (rather than what my ego needs) maybe I will get to change the world, maybe I will be well known for something, but that’s not the goal, because I can’t control that, I can only control my day to day life.

posts.title: Scottish Government bid to increase GPs will provide 'high standard of care'
posts.text:
Scottish Government bid to increase GPs will provide 'high standard of care' West Kilbride surgery has had to bring in locum doctors this year after all the GPs quit 
MSP Kenneth Gibson has said that people in the North Coast and Cumbraes can expect 'a high standard of care' as the Scottish Government look to increase the number of GPs by at least 800 over the next decade in Scotland. Health Secretary Shona Robison told GPs at a special BMA conference that the move will ensure long term sustainability of GP practice. There are currently around 4,900 GPs in Scotland. Ms Robison also announced £7.5 million in 2018-19 to recruit and retain GPs, particularly in rural areas. Support will be available for all 160 rural and remote practices, including ‘golden hello’ payments of £10,000 to GPs taking up their first post in a rural practice and relocation packages of up to £5,000. Ms Robison said: “The new GP contract, a historic joint agreement between the SNP Government and the BMA, will ensure that GPs are able to spend more time with patients and less time on bureaucracy. If accepted, it will help cut doctors’ overall workload and make general practice an even more attractive career prospect. As multi-disciplinary teams are developed further within GP practices, our ambition is to increase the number of GPs by at least 800 over ten years to ensure a sustainable service for the future.” Added Kenneth Gibson MSP said "The SNP Government’s commitment to invest £7.5 million, including expanding the remote and rural incentive scheme and relocation funds, will have a real impact going forward. Ultimately, this will ensure people both here in Ayrshire and across Scotland continue to receive a high standard of care.” Chair of BMA Scotland's GP Committee Dr Alan McDevitt said: “Working towards delivering 800 additional GPs for Scotland is a sensible and realistic target for the years ahead. Together with the wider measures in the proposed contract to make general practice a more attractive career, I believe that this can have a significant impact on improving GP recruitment and retention.”
